@farokh @iwwon_official @CryptoMories @opensea A few thoughts. https://t.co/pHiDdiFEwB
And FWIW â€“ Iâ€™m not a lawyer but I have studied the situation and stand with @iwwon_official. I know a shakedown when I see itâ€¦.
Join us. Join the â€œweâ€ movement. We will upend â€œIâ€ together. Upend evil. Upend destiny. Upend everything and rise higher! We are web3 and we are legion.

But we have chosen â€œweâ€ over â€œIâ€. We do not fight because we care about ourselves. None of us have the power to stop the battle axe from falling. But together we are more. Together we are heroes. Together we are a league.

Thereâ€™s a villain in our midst. And the villain wields the letter â€œIâ€ like a sharpened battle axe. For him there is only â€œIâ€. He wants to exist like the letter itself. Every action is for â€œIâ€ and nothing else. An â€œIâ€ floating on its own needs. A life connected to nothing but â€œIâ€.
The speech would sound something like this:

The whole situation feels like a dramatic movie is unfolding in front of our eyes.

I can picture a General standing in front of his/her troops and delivering a truly motivational speech. The energy would be palpable and the masses would feel like theyâ€™ve already won.

To be clear, the process still needs time to play out because copyright infringement claims are serious matters and there are governing bodies that will be ultimate arbiter of â€œright and wrongâ€. 

But itâ€™s pretty clear where the court of public opinion standsâ€¦.

Why would they do this?  The simple answer is that the attack is not just on the CryptoMories project, but also an open assault on the web3 ethos and the community is not going to let this stand without a fight.

The entire NFT community has shown support for the Mories family by buying Mories on the platforms that theyâ€™re still listed on and taking to Twitter and other social media platforms to share their kind words.
https://t.co/rZoXssgH8H

In the words of @iwwon_official (the creative genius behind the Mories project):

â€œIn a space where we pretend to share, support and collaborate, attacking another collection, team, and community this way is in my opinion not only counterproductive, but extremely sad.â€

Someone from the NFT world claimed that one of the Mories traits was a copyright infringement and he asked for an absurd amount of money to go away.
 
DMCA cases need to be taken seriously, and OpenSea did just that with their â€œact first, ask questions laterâ€ delisting action.

The power of the collective in web3 is truly astounding.

This week, @CryptoMories was delisted from OpenSea due to a DMCA takedown request. The project is beloved in the space, and as the facts came out, the community threw their weight behind the Mories family. ğŸ§µğŸ‘‡

RT @Ryan_Falvey: Twitter should create a button that automatically retweets all of Frankâ€™s threads. Just Frankâ€™s though.

@SahilBloom The best investments are non-consensus but turn consensus based on very specific learnings.

If "one thing" can turn a non-consensus investment into a consensus then the risk can be massively rewarded once the company is de-risked.

The losing strategy during the pandemic was to be a VC firm paying-up for consensus deals because they were losing to Top Tier VCs but felt the need to deploy capital. I wouldnâ€™t want to be an LP in one of these funds because the results will probably make you cry.

And great VC firms that looked for non-consensus alpha during the pandemic should also do well. Their â€œopportunityâ€ was to find investments where their view of value was greater than the consensus perception of value.

But Top Tier VC firms that chased consensus investments during the pandemic should do well. The â€œopportunityâ€ wasnâ€™t generated by pricing deals carefully. It was generated by winning as much â€œright hand tail alphaâ€ as possible.

For the â€œpandemic vintageâ€ as a whole, returns are likely to come in worse than the vintages generated in the 2010s. Entry valuations are up as are the probabilities of success. Capital efficiency is good but getting worse. Exit valuations are good but getting worse.

With this framework in mind, the question about whether the â€œpandemic vintageâ€ will underperform can be diagnosed.

We need to ask and answer the question: 

Is the â€œOpportunity = Value â€“ Perceptionâ€ equation stable, improving or declining?

Impact to early investors: Disciplined investors are paying up for businesses that have reduced odds of failure and truly massive potential outcomes

And investors who are willing to do the work to find fantastic non-consensus opportunities should outperform the market handily.

But non-consensus companies are risky because raising downstream capital can be tricky until they de-risk the business. 

And first time Founders are risky because they donâ€™t have the same access to resources, capital and talent that will follow them to the ends of the Earth.

But if Opportunity = Value â€“ Perception, then the way to produce outsized returns is to find non-consensus opportunities where the odds of success are greater than what the broad investor community believes.

Getting this right is important because paying up for the wrong type of startup can crush returns.

Entry valuations for â€œconsensusâ€ oriented investments have mooned in the past few years. 

And entry valuations for â€œserial Foundersâ€ reflect the belief that â€œwinners winâ€.

Great investors know when to pay up for opportunities that are near-certain winners or opportunities that have outsized â€œif everything goes rightâ€ outcomes. Mediocre investors arenâ€™t as discerning. Poor investors pay up for everything because itâ€™s how they win deals.

ENTRY VALUATIONS

Since the magnitude of right-hand tail outcomes have increased dramatically, itâ€™s logical that entry prices have also increased. But not all startups have the same potential which is where investor skill and insight come into play.

Late-stage multiples

Early investors benefit from cheap downstream capital. Multiples have been high (cheap capital) but there are signs that this is changing as we speak given public market comps.

Impact to early investors: Positive relative to historical norms but changing

Talent war

The available talent pool hasnâ€™t kept pace with the Cambrian explosion of well-funded startups. Hiring and retaining talent dilutes investor returns because it consumes cash and equity.

Impact to early investors: Negative

Startup tools

Itâ€™s easier than ever to leverage existing infrastructure players to launch functionality. The impact is profound because most tech heavy startups live and die by how quickly they can ship code

Impact to early investors: Positive

CAPITAL EFFICIENCY

There are many forces at play that impact how capital efficient a startup is. Generic trends can be examined, but dilution is more a function of â€œbusiness model specific forcesâ€ than the other drivers.

With this said, a few macro forces at work include:

Public investors have internalized how good well-run tech companies can be relative to the incumbents theyâ€™re attacking.

Even with the recent correction in the public markets, exit valuations are very healthy from a historical standpoint.

Impact to early investors: Positive

EXIT VALUATION

VC backed companies are staying private longer than they did in the past which means that more enterprise value is accruing in the private markets.

The best are staying private long enough to â€œpriceâ€ at multi, deca and even centi-billion dollar valuations.

What is true is that shipping code on time and budget is easier than itâ€™s been in the past.

What is true is that there are established â€œgo to marketâ€ strategies that can help scale startups faster and with more certainty than in the past.

Impact to early investors: Positive

What is true is that launching a startup is easier and less expensive than itâ€™s been in the past.

What is true is that capital availability has given startups more time to crack the code on their businesses than theyâ€™ve had in the past.

PROBABILITY OF SUCCESS

Startups arenâ€™t uniform beasts. Unseating an incumbent or creating a market the world hasnâ€™t seen before isnâ€™t easy, but the reality is that some spaces are easier to disrupt than others. Startups chances of success span the entire risk spectrum.

An oversimplified value formula: 

Return = (Exit Valuation/Entry Valuation - Dilution From New Shares Issued For Employees and Investors Between the Entry and Exit Period) * (Probability of Success)

So what do we know about how the key drivers are changing?

The next step is to lay out the main drivers of returns and how theyâ€™re changing.

A simple framework that I like to use collapses the drivers into four major categories:

Entry valuation, Capital Efficiency, Exit Valuation and Probability of Success

Individual investments will follow their own paths but a â€œvintageâ€ will succumb to the forces of the mega-trends.

And because â€œOpportunity = Value â€“ Perceptionâ€, top quartile managers will always outperform the â€œvintageâ€ definitionally.

So when answering the question: â€œHow will a vintage of investments performâ€, a good place to start is to examine the key drivers of return and how theyâ€™re moving.

10-year VC returns have been fantastic so another 10-year period of similar performance would be welcomed!

Buying one lottery ticket with your own money can be fun but assembling an investment portfolio with other peopleâ€™s money is different.

It kind-of-sort-of feels like you should know what the risk/return profile is of your investments. Your LPs probably care about this.

Only looking at a theoretical exit valuation is the equivalent to buying a lottery ticket without understanding the odds of winning. 

Many factors influence returns including a variety of exogenous factors. â€œReturns mathâ€ isnâ€™t based on set-it-and-forget-it formulas.

If you want to be a top decile investor, itâ€™s important to do the work to understand the potential return of any investment. And potential returns arenâ€™t only a function of the â€œexit valuation in a success scenarioâ€.

Observation #4:

Buying a winning lottery ticket isnâ€™t the same as being a great investor. Both produce fantastic economic returns but only one is repeatable.

Repeatability requires skill and discipline. Repeatability requires feedback and learning. Repeatability requires work.

Observation #3:

The power law is used to justify lofty valuations. â€œYou canâ€™t pay too much for the best companiesâ€ is mostly true.

Itâ€™s also true that building a portfolio made exclusively of â€œbest companiesâ€ is a fantasy because theyâ€™re difficult to spot before they break out.

This isnâ€™t a new phenomenon. The â€œpower lawâ€ can be trusted as a fundamental force of the universe with the same level of certainty that every morning the sun will rise in the East and every evening it will set in the West.

Observation #2:

Even with the correction in the public markets, the best VC backed companies have produced amazing outcomes for early stage Investors. Any early stage Investor who found at least one â€œright hand tail companyâ€ returned their fund many times over.

This leads to a critical VC truism thatâ€™s often overlooked:

Opportunity = Value â€“ Perception

If every investor saw every investment opportunity the same way then returns would collapse to the risk adjusted cost of capital. There wouldnâ€™t be â€œtop quartileâ€ managers anymore.

Investor interest varies because each investor evaluates the risk/return profile using its own methods.

Consensus startups attract capital at higher prices than non-consensus startups because the investor community believes these startups will succeed with high probability.

Observation #1:

VC returns are driven by investing in companies that arenâ€™t fully de-risked that ultimately succeed because the risks never materialize.

A lot of things can skink a startup, but the best dodge bullets, avoid landmines and ultimately create enterprise value.

People are curious how the â€œpandemic vintageâ€ of startups is going to perform. 

Are returns going to collapse because entry points are 3-5X what they were years ago?

Will the public markets correction crush returns?

A ğŸ§µabout how "Opportunity = Value â€“ Perception"
